abstract.p: Adam Searing letter on health-advocacy organizations that are set up with drug industry financing (Oct 5 article)

block.p: Re ''With Quiet, Unseen Ties, Drug Makers Sway Debate'' (front page, Oct. 5):

Those of us at the state and national levels who advocate better health care for ordinary people have to deal with low salaries, indifferent legislators, well-financed opponents in tasseled loafers and seemingly intractable problems that rarely have easy solutions. Now our grass-roots groups have the additional roadblock of these biased ''Astroturf'' advocacy groups that are set up with drug industry financing.
Re ''With Quiet, Unseen Ties, Drug Makers Sway Debate'' (front page, Oct. 5):

Those of us at the state and national levels who advocate better health care for ordinary people have to deal with low salaries, indifferent legislators, well-financed opponents in tasseled loafers and seemingly intractable problems that rarely have easy solutions. Now our grass-roots groups have the additional roadblock of these biased ''Astroturf'' advocacy groups that are set up with drug industry financing.

By making legislators suspicious of all health advocacy organizations, these efforts make it harder for real patients and real people to be heard on the high cost of drugs and a variety of other health issues.
The writer is project director, North Carolina Health Access Coalition.
